title: Management of Incidentally Discovered Pineal Cyst on CT and MRI: Recommendations from the ACR Incidental Findings Committee - Journal of the American College of Radiology

blocks.alt: Cover Image - Journal of the American College of Radiology, Volume 23, Issue 1

blocks.text: Overview of the ACR Incidental Findings Program
The Consensus Process: Management of Incidental Pineal Cysts
Elements of the Flowcharts: Color Coding

Fig. 1 Management of incidental pineal cyst detected on MRI of the brain. (1) An incidental lesion is defined as lacking clinical signs or symptoms of nausea or vomiting, papilledema, visual disturbances, Parinauds syndrome, hemiparesis, hemisensory aberration, vertigo, syncope, migraine, seizures, and isolated headache. Isolated headache without additional symptoms of increased intracranial pressure, mass effect, or hydrocephalus is not sufficient to indicate neurosurgical consultation. If at any time such symptoms develop, the patient should be referred for a neurosurgical consultation. Clinician discretion should be used when considering patients who are unable to undergo treatment, have limited life expectancy, or have substantial comorbidities. (2) If at any time during initial or follow-up imaging signal changes in the tectum occur, hydrocephalus is present, or mass effect on the aqueduct is present, refer the case for neurosurgical consult. (3) A simple cyst is defined as having a thin or imperceptible wall and uniform fluid signal on T2-weighted imaging and fluid-attenuated inversion recovery imaging. (4) A Nonsimple cyst is defined as having a thickened wall or nodular component or signal inconsistent with simple fluid. IF = incidental finding.

Fig. 2 Management of incidental pineal cyst detected on CT of the head. (1) An incidental lesion is defined as lacking clinical signs or symptoms of nausea or vomiting, papilledema, visual disturbances, Parinauds syndrome, hemiparesis, hemisensory aberration, vertigo, syncope, migraine, seizures, and isolated headache. Isolated headache without additional symptoms of increased intracranial pressure, mass effect, or hydrocephalus is not sufficient to indicate neurosurgical consultation. If at any time such symptoms develop, the patient should be referred for a neurosurgical consultation. Clinician discretion should be used when considering patients who are unable to undergo treatment, have limited life expectancy, or have substantial comorbidities. (2) If at any time during initial or follow-up imaging a signal abnormality in the tectum occurs, or hydrocephalus is present, or mass effect on the aqueduct (narrowing or compromised) is seen, refer the case for neurosurgical consult. (3) A simple cyst is defined as having a thin or imperceptible wall and uniform fluid attenuation. Simple fluid follows cerebrospinal fluid signal on T1, T2, fluid-attenuated inversion recovery, and diffusion-weighted images and cerebrospinal fluid density on CT. (4) A nonsimple cyst is defined as having a thickened wall, a nodular component, or nonsimple fluid density. (5) If stable, recommend managing as second follow-up for >15-mm simple cyst on MRI. If size or complexity increases, neurosurgical consultation is recommended.
Implications and Risks of Incidental Pineal Cysts Detected on CT or MRI
